theme.title: The staff
theme.para: In the Western musical notation system music is written on specially printed paper called 'manuscript paper' (see picture).

The manuscript paper is organized as sets of horizontal lines, named 'staves' (each group of horizontal lines is called a 'staff', with 'staves' as the plural; in British English the word 'staff' is old-fashioned and rarely used; they use the word 'stave' instead). A staff is a set of five horizontal lines, numbered from bottom to top; the bottom line is the first line and the top line is the fifth line:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language es iso-8859-1) (instrumento (datosMusica (clave Sol noVisible)(tonalidad Do) (metrica 2 4 noVisible)(texto "1" dx:50 dy:55) (barra Doble noVisible) )))

theme.para: The four spaces between the staff lines, are important and are also numbered from bottom to top:

The musical symbols are placed on the staff. The symbols for notes are placed either on a line or on a space and the musical pitch (low or high) represented by the symbol is determined by the position of the note on the staff. Notes on the higher lines/spaces have higer pitch than those on the lower ones. Lesson to the next scale:

score.music: (metrica 2 4 noVisible) (n e4 r)(n f4 r)(n g4 r)(n a4 r)(n b4 r)(n c5 r) (n d5 r)(n e5 r)(n f5 r)(barra Doble noVisible)

theme.para: Music on the staff is read from left to right.
